I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People's Republic of China (PRC) is undertaking reforms to 
strengthen public finances.  These  reforms  encompass a  number  of  areas  to  enhance  the 
efficiency and equity of the fiscal system and improve access to, and the quality of, public 
services. To strengthen this effort, the Government requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) to Support Fiscal Policy Reforms in High Priority 
Sectors. A TA Fact-Finding Mission held detailed discussions in April 2008 with the Ministry of 
Finance (MOF), the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security, the Ministry of Health, 
the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), and international agencies on 
objectives and scope, implementation arrangements, and cost of the proposed TA project. This 
report reflects ADB’s findings and understandings reached with the Government on the TA 
project  design,  costs,  and  its  implementation  arrangements.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The MOF sought ADB technical assistance to support fiscal reforms in three strategic 
areas:  (i)  fiscal  policy  support  for  the  health  sector  reforms  that  are  being  finalized;  (ii) 
assessment and management of the risks from the growing explicit, implicit, and contingent 
liabilities  of  subnational  governments;  and  (iii)  assessment  of  the  causes  of  escalation  of 
administrative costs, and recommendations for containment measures.   
 
A.  Fiscal Policy Support for the Health Sector Reforms 
 
3.  Improving people’s health is one of the strategic priorities of the PRC under the 11th 
Five-Year Plan. The Government strategy seeks to provide equitable, efficient, and quality 
public  health  and  basic  medical  services  for  all  citizens.  Total  health  care  expenditures 
represented 4.7% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2006.2 Rapid increases in health care 
costs have outpaced public expenditure for health, which declined as a share of total health 
care spending from 36% in 1980 to 18% in 2006.3 Low levels of health insurance have led to a 
sharp increase in out-of-pocket expenses for individuals, which reached 50% of total national 
health expenditures in 2006, compared with 21% in 1980.4 Spiraling health costs coexist with 
gaps in quality of care and issues of equity and efficiency in the use of public resources, 
particularly  in  rural  and  underdeveloped  areas.  Increasingly  concerned  about  these 
developments (particularly declining access to affordable health services), the Government in 
2006 established an interministerial working group of 16 agencies chaired by the NDRC to 
prepare a comprehensive health reform framework. While the basic reform framework is being 
readied  for  official  release,  more  detailed  plans  are  currently  being  drafted  by  the  core 
responsible agencies.

most strained and where financial protection through health insurance is not adequate.

2   
4.  The interministerial group has reportedly reached a broad consensus on the strategic 
directions for strengthening health insurance and the public health system. Models for funding 
grassroots health facilities (urban community health centers, village health clinics, and township 
health centers) have been discussed within the interministerial group. Two options were put 
forward. Under the first, the Government will take responsibility for medical staff salaries, and 
will manage health facilities’ operational expenditure and income separately. The second option 
is for a system funded from several sources (fiscal budget, health insurance, and out-of-pocket 
funds), and the Government will set subsidies/support for medical institutions under a service-
purchasing model. A decision is yet to be taken on this matter by the State Council. Options are 
also discussed on provider payment mechanisms. These options will have different incentive 
structures and are likely to impact differently on equity, efficiency, and quality of health services. 
 
5.  Given the potentially far-reaching fiscal and social impact of the alternative funding 
options and provider payment mechanisms, the Government has requested the assistance of 
ADB in pilot-testing various models for funding grassroots health facilities. The results of the 
pilot test are expected to provide an empirical basis for determining optimal financing models for 
health facilities at the grassroots level to improve access to good quality, cost-effective, basic 
health care. Thus, the outcome of the pilot will help the Government decide the level and pattern 
of spending on grassroots health care facilities. The TA project builds on previous ADB support 
in the health sector to the PRC for:5 (i) research to help catalyze the Government’s pilot testing 
of the new Rural Cooperative Medical System, (ii) establishing mechanisms for community 
participation to enhance system management and implementation at the grassroots level, (iii) 
public nutrition and noncommunicable diseases, and (iv) ADB cooperation with the NDRC in 
assessing rural health services.   
 
B.  Management of Subnational Government Liabilities  
 
6.  The subnational governments are prohibited by law to borrow directly from the market. 
They may only borrow from the central Government and external aid agencies as onlending 
from the central Government. Yet, in practice, subnational governments have been borrowing 
indirectly using various vehicles, including state-owned enterprises and other state agencies 
such  as  hospitals  and  educational  institutions.  The  magnitude  of  these  borrowings  is  not 
captured on budget. There is no institutional arrangement to account for and manage the risks 
from these liabilities, and hence their magnitude is not known. Keeping in mind the potential 
risks of such unregulated borrowings, the Government set up a taskforce in the MOF in 2005 to 
make recommendations for managing subnational liabilities. The responsibilities of the taskforce 
have been given to the newly created Local Governments' Indebtedness Management Division 
in the MOF. This division will be responsible for consolidating, monitoring, and managing the 
indirectly created implicit liabilities of subnational governments.  
 
7.  Even though subnational government liabilities are a growing concern, their magnitude is 
unknown  partly  due  to  the  complexities  involved  in  their  measurement.  A  blueprint  for 
establishing a risk-rating and early warning system for continuous and accurate monitoring of 
local government indebtedness is yet to be prepared. The Government sought ADB technical 
assistance to support the work of the Local Governments' Indebtedness Management Division

C.  Study and Management of Administrative Costs 
 
8.  The current level of administrative costs in the PRC is considered high for the PRC’s 
level of development. Even so, these costs have been increasing in recent years; this is a 
source of concern as well as criticism from both within and outside the Government. Preliminary 
investigations of the MOF pointed to three main contributing factors: (i) the modernization of 
state assets, (ii) the introduction of new branches of Government, and (iii) increases in civil 
servant wages. In addition to the high level and growth of administrative costs, the Government 
is also concerned by their vertical and regional imbalances. While the central and provincial 
governments  have  high  administrative  costs  backed  up  by  corresponding  budgets,  local 
governments below provincial level find it difficult to obtain resources for effectively discharging 
their essential administrative functions. Further, there are regional imbalances amongst local 
governments, resulting in substantially lower administrative budgets for the western and central 
regions compared to the governments in the eastern region. The Government is keen to (i) 
study the causes of high administrative costs and their rapid growth, and the existing vertical 
and horizontal imbalances; and (ii) recommend measures and specific targets to contain costs 
and mitigate vertical and horizontal imbalances. In this regard, the Government intends to learn 
from relevant international experience.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The  impact  of  the  TA  project  is  increased  fiscal  effectiveness  and  equity  through 
improved public resource management in key areas: health sector financing, risk from local 
government  debt,  and  administrative  cost  containment.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  project  is 
deepened fiscal reforms in key areas by (i) improving the equity, efficiency, and sustainability of 
grassroots health care facilities; (ii) efficiently managing subnational government implicit and 
explicit debt; and (iii) effectively containing the increase in administrative costs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA project will have three major outputs: (i) fiscal policy support for the health sector 
reforms, (ii) management of subnational government liabilities, and (iii) study and management 
of administrative costs.   
 
11.  Fiscal Policy Support for the Health Sector Reforms (Output A). The health sector 
component of the TA project will have the following three subcomponents:  
 
(i)  Subcomponent  1:  Assistance  with  designing  the  pilot  project  and  the 
accompanying monitoring and evaluation system. The TA project will help 
design a pilot project to test cost-effective and equitable financing models for 
basic health care and develop a monitoring and evaluation tool to track and 
evaluate the performance of the pilot. The monitoring and evaluation tool will be

4   
developed as a “pre-post experiment with an appropriate control group”.6 The 
financing models to be tested will be finalized after the State Council’s decision 
on the piloting arrangements. This subcomponent will also develop a quality 
assessment tool to monitor the quality of the implementation of the pilot project.  
(ii)  Subcomponent 2: Monitoring and evaluation of the pilot project. Based on 
the  outputs  of  subcomponent  1,  the  TA  project  will  carry  out  independent 
monitoring and evaluation of the pilot project, including the initial provision of 
basic training to concerned local health and administrative staff for the proper 
implementation of the pilot project and the monitoring and evaluation system. 
The implementation of the pilot project will be the responsibility of the central and 
concerned local governments. Monitoring will be carried out over two budget 
cycles with a midterm evaluation after the first year and final evaluation at the 
end of the project. 
(iii)  Subcomponent 3: Policy recommendations for reforming the financing of 
grassroots health facilities. Based on the evaluation reports, the TA project will 
develop policy recommendations for central and local governments. The policy 
recommendations  will  be  discussed  by  stakeholders  and  presented  to  the 
Government. 
 
12.  The total duration of this component will be 30 months. An outline of terms of reference 
for the consultants and the estimated need for consulting inputs are in Appendix 3. 
 
13.  Management of Subnational Government Liabilities (Output B).This output will have 
five objectives: (i) introduce the best international practices for measuring the explicit, implicit, 
and  contingent  liabilities  incurred  by  the  agencies  controlled  by  provincial  and  local 
governments; (ii) estimate the magnitude of subnational government liabilities; (iii) prepare a 
blueprint for establishing a risk-rating and early warning system of international standard for 
continuous and accurate monitoring of local government indebtedness; (iv) study the feasibility 
of issuance of securities in the market by subnational governments; and (v) organize workshops 
to discuss policy issues on local-debt management. The magnitude of subnational liabilities 
under item (ii) will be estimated using representative samples from one province from each of 
the six regions in the PRC. Due to the sensitivities in the disclosure of subnational government 
liabilities, the Government preferred single-source selection of the College of Finance and 
Taxation  of  the  People’s  University,  also  known  as  the  China  Fiscal  and  Financial  Policy 
Research Center.7 In addition, resource persons will be engaged for the international seminar. 
This output is expected to be completed in 18 months. 
 
14.  Study and Management of Administrative Costs (Output C). This component will (i) 
assess the causes of the high administrative costs and their rapid growth in recent years; (ii) 
examine the reasons for vertical and horizontal imbalances at the subnational level; and (iii) 
recommend  mitigating  measures,  incentives,  and  institutional  arrangements  necessary  for 
containing administrative costs and reducing imbalances. The Government will take note of 
international  best  practices  in  this  field,  including  the  use  of  e-governance  solutions.  The 
Government also intends to estimate off-budget administrative expenditure on a pilot basis to 
gauge the true magnitude of the problem and learn about hidden sources of cost escalation. 
The  outputs  will  include  (i)  a  research  framework,  incorporating  relevant  international 
experience, for fieldwork to estimate administrative costs including from off-budget sources (on

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA project is estimated at $1,300,000 equivalent. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $1,000,000 equivalent. The TA project will be financed on a grant 
basis  from  ADB’s  technical  assistance  funding  program.  The  Government  will  provide  the 
remaining $300,000 of local currency costs in kind, to cover office accommodation, counterpart 
staff, and other related services. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The International Department of the MOF will be the Executing Agency (EA) for the TA 
project.8 The Department of Social Security of the MOF will be the Implementing Agency (IA) for 
output A. An interministerial pilot review group under MOF will oversee output A. The group will 
provide  strategic  orientation  to  the  TA  project  and  feedback  on  its  outputs.  The  Budget 
Department  of  the  MOF  will  be  the  IA  for  output  B.  The  Department  of  Administrative, 
Legislative, and Judicial Agencies of the MOF will be the IA for output C. The International 
Department of the MOF, as the EA, in consultation with the IAs, will supervise the day-to-day 
working of the consultants and take responsibility for administering national training programs, 
seminars,  workshops,  and  in-country  study  visits.  To  facilitate  implementation  of  these 
components, ADB may establish an advance payment facility for the EA as needed, and/or 
utilize direct payment.9 ADB will assist the EA in facilitating the international study tours. The 
College of Finance and Taxation of the People’s University will be engaged on single-source 
selection basis due to the confidential nature of the study for output B; remaining consultants 
will be selected on competitive basis. All consultants for the TA project will be engaged in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). Procurement will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Supporting Fiscal Reforms in High Priority 
Sectors, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Fiscal Policy Support for the Health Sector Reforms (Output A)1 
 
1.  The design of the pilot project will require 8 person-months of consulting services, 
comprising 6 person-months of national experts specializing in health systems reform and 
evaluation, and health economics; and 2 person-months of international consultant services. 
The national consultant on health systems reform and evaluation will be the team leader of the 
group of consultants. The international consultant will serve as advisor to the Department of 
Social Security in the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the national consultants. 
 
1.  Team Leader and Senior Health Reform and Evaluation Specialist (national, 
3 person-months) 
 
2.  The specialist will do the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Serve  as  the  team  leader  of  the  national  and  international  consultants,  and 
ensure timely completion of the pilot project design. 
(ii)  Carry out field visits and liaise closely with local government agencies as needed. 
(iii)  Assist the Department of Social Security in the MOF in designing and locating 
the pilot project to test financing models for grassroots health facilities. Suitable 
sampling methods will be used in this process to ensure that the results of pilots 
are  valid.  The  consultant  will  produce  an  operations  manual  on  the 
implementation of the pilot project, including objectives, detailed activities, and 
required system changes, funding sources, and responsibilities. 
(iv)  Design a monitoring and evaluation tool to track and evaluate the pilot project. 
The monitoring and evaluation tool will provide strong evidence for informed 
policy making. It will be developed as a “pre-post experiment with an appropriate 
control group”.2 Performances measurements will be defined reflecting, among 
other  things,  variables  on  equity  (accessibility),  quality  (including  patient 
satisfaction), efficiency, and effectiveness. Data collection will consist of routine 
hospital records information and data from health facility and household surveys. 
Data will be collected to control for variables such as quality, case severity, risk 
selection, and possible cost-shifting. The appropriateness of using qualitative 
methods will be explored. The consultant will produce an operations manual on 
the implementation of the monitoring and evaluation tool, including objectives, 
detailed activities, collaboration with local governments, data collection methods 
and  instruments,  data  encoding  and  analysis,  reporting  system,  and 
responsibilities. The tool should remain realistic and its design should take into 
account  budgetary  constraints,  operational  feasibility,  required  level  of 
robustness of findings, and the deadline for submitting the evaluation results to 
the interministerial group. 
(v)  Develop  a  simple  quality  assessment  tool  to  monitor  the  quality  of  the 
implementation  of  the  pilot  project.  The  tool  will  help  in  verifying  at  regular 
intervals whether the pilot project is implemented satisfactorily. The tool could be

(iii)  contribute to the development of the operations manual on the pilot test. 
 
4.  For the design of the monitoring and evaluation system, the specialist will 
 
(i)  consult previous studies and evaluation reports on the health system of the 
People's Republic of China (PRC) and identify methodological weaknesses that 
will be addressed in designing the tool; 
(ii)  determine,  after  taking  into  account  the  MOF’s  views,  the  most  appropriate 
financial indicators to be measured and the related sources of data; 
(iii)  design appropriate data collection instruments related to financial matters; and 
(iv)  contribute to the development of the operations manual on the monitoring and 
evaluation system. 
 
3.  Senior Health Evaluation Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
5.  The international specialist will have global experience in health reforms and evaluation 
systems, including substantial scientific publications, and be familiar with the PRC health sector. 
The specialist will  
 
(i)  have international expertise in evaluation systems and contribute to identifying 
lessons for the PRC; 
(ii)  provide methodological and technical inputs into the design of the pilot test and 
the monitoring and evaluation tool; 
(iii)  provide three critical reviews of the work of the national consultants; and  
(iv)  contribute to the quality of the final report detailing the three subcomponents of 
output A (which will include Chinese and English versions). 
 
  4.  National Monitoring and Evaluation and Capacity Building Specialist (firm) 
 
6.  A qualified national entity (firm) will be recruited as service providers. The entity will be in 
charge of independent monitoring and evaluation and regular assessment of the quality of the 
implementation of the pilot project. It is estimated that implementation of the pilot project will last 
24 months. The entity should demonstrate strong competence in health system evaluation and 
should  draw  on  national  and  international  expertise.  Subject  to  agreement  on  detailed 
breakdown  of  consultant  input,  the  entity’s  team  will  consist  of  (i)  one  or  more  national 
consultants (24 person-months) specializing in health systems reform and evaluation, and (ii) 
one  international  consultant  (2  person-months)  with  strong  expertise  in  health  system 
evaluation. Short-term resource persons to assist in monitoring and evaluation will be proposed

Appendix 3  11 
to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recruited by the Department of Social Security in the 
MOF. The entity will implement the following tasks: 
 
(i)  With MOF, ADB, and the individual consultants, jointly review the outputs of 
subcomponent  1,  in  particular  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  strategy  and 
capacity building. 
(ii)  Provide basic training to local health and administrative staff involved in the 
implementation of the pilot and the data collection for monitoring and evaluation 
using the operations manual developed for pilot projects under the technical 
assistance (TA) project. 
(iii)  Collect routine information data from health facilities and the health department. 
(iv)  Implement regular health facility and household surveys, and carry out qualitative 
data collection as included in the design of the monitoring and evaluation tool. 
(v)  Apply  control  measures  to  check  quality  of  secondary  data  collected  from 
facilities and the administration. 
(vi)  Encode and process data as designed under the TA project, and analyze data 
and prepare quarterly report for the Department of Social Security in the MOF. 
(vii)  Carry  out  quarterly  assessment  and  midterm  review  of  the  quality  of  the 
implementation of the pilot project using the tool developed under the TA project. 
(viii)  Present  the  status  of  implementation  of  current  results  of  the  pilot  to  the 
interministerial group at midterm and towards the end of the pilot project. 
(ix)  Present  the  results  of  the  pilot  project  in  a  stakeholder  workshop  (including 
external partners) organized by the Department of Social Security in the MOF.  
(x)  Prepare a research paper on the results of the pilot, including draft policy and 
operational recommendations for suitable financing mechanisms for grassroots 
health facilities in the PRC.  
 
B.  Management of Subnational Government Liabilities (Output B) 
 
1.  National Debt Management Specialist (firm) 
 
7.  The selected national specialist firm will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Analyze the structural, institutional, and incentive-related reasons for the rapid 
build up of implicit and explicit contingent liabilities of subnational governments. 
(ii)  Using  internationally  accepted  definitions  and  methodologies,  estimate  the 
magnitude  of  subnational  government  liabilities  based  on  a  scientific 
representative sample drawn from six provinces representing the six regions. 
(iii)  Conduct  research  into  the  feasibility  of  subnational  governments  issuing 
securities in the market.  
(iv)  Prepare a blueprint for establishing a risk-rating and early warning system for 
continuous and accurate monitoring of local government indebtedness. 
(v)  Assist the MOF in organizing workshops and/or seminars, and training programs 
on subnational debt management and policy. 
(vi)  Assist the MOF in making policy recommendations to the State Council for sound 
management and control of subnational government debt and liabilities. 
 
2.  International  Public  Debt  Management  Expert  (1.5  person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
8.  The international expert will carry out the following tasks:

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(i)  Prepare a report on the international best practices for measuring the magnitude 
of explicit, implicit, and contingent liabilities incurred by the agencies controlled 
by subnational governments. Advise the MOF on how to estimate subnational 
government liabilities.  
(ii)  Critically review the national institution’s analysis on structural reasons for the 
rapid build up of implicit and explicit contingent liabilities. 
(iii)  Critically  review  the  national  institution’s  feasibility  study  on  subnational 
government’s issuance of securities in the market. 
(iv)  Assist in the preparation of a blueprint for establishing a risk-rating and early 
warning system of international standard for continuous and accurate monitoring 
of local government indebtedness. 
 
C.  Study and Management of Administrative Costs (Output C) 
 
1.  National Public Finance/Administration Specialists (21 person-months) 
 
9.  The national specialists will: 
 
(i)  Review relevant existing studies. 
(ii)  Compile relevant international experience. 
(iii)  Evaluate alternative definitions of administrative costs, in light of international 
standards. 
(iv)  Conduct (a) a structural and trend analysis of aggregate and subnational level 
administrative costs for 1997–2007, (b) an economies of scale analysis (based 
on the volume of administrative costs per capita) across all provinces for 1997–
2007, and (c) an analysis of the impact of differential regulatory responsibilities 
and levels of development across regions on the administrative costs. 
(v)  Analyze the causes of increasing administrative costs, distinguishing between 
legitimate causes (including the stage of economic development, size of the civil 
service,  and  size  of  the  wage  bill),  structural  causes  (inefficiencies,  and 
weaknesses in internal control mechanisms), and illegitimate causes (including 
overspending and wastage). 
(vi)  Estimate  the  magnitude  of  extra-budgetary  financing  of  administrative  costs 
based on a representative sample study of six provinces (two each from the 
eastern, central, and western regions). 
(vii)  Assist in conducting workshops and training programs. 
(viii)  Recommended measures to contain administrative costs at a level appropriate to 
the PRC’s stage of economic development. 
 
2.  International Public Administration Expert (1.5 person-months) 
 
10.  The consultant will 
 
(i)  assist with the development of the research framework by incorporating relevant 
international experience and lessons learned; and 
(ii)  assist  with  the  finalization  of  the  research  report,  including  policy 
recommendations,  by  incorporating  relevant  international  experiences  and 
lessons.

Appendix 3  13 
3.  International Resource Persons (15 person-days) 
 
11.  The international resource persons will facilitate the conference/workshops, and prepare 
short discussion papers and presentations on their country experiences on administrative cost 
increases and the measures taken to contain them.
